title: Network Security Fundamentals
description: Threats, attacks, mitigations, and Cisco device hardening

glance.label: Threat types
glance.detail: Info theft, Data loss, ID theft, Disruption

blocks.content: Intruders who gain access by modifying software or exploiting vulnerabilities are called threat actors. Once inside, four types of threat can occur:

items.title: Information Theft
items.description: Breaking into a computer to obtain confidential information. Can be sold or misused ‚Äî e.g. stealing R&D data.

items.title: Data Loss & Manipulation
items.description: Altering or destroying data on the network, making it unreliable or unusable.

items.title: Identity Theft
items.description: Using stolen credentials to impersonate a legitimate user and gain unauthorised access.

items.title: Disruption of Service
items.description: Taking network services offline so legitimate users cannot access them.

blocks.label: Vulnerability
blocks.content: The degree of weakness in a network or device. Some vulnerability is inherent in all devices ‚Äî routers, switches, servers, even security devices. Endpoints like servers and desktops are most commonly targeted.
3 Types of Vulnerability

rows: Technological
Weaknesses built into protocols and operating systems
HTTP, FTP, ICMP, SNMP, SMTP are all inherently insecure. OS weaknesses documented by CERT.
Configuration
Devices left with insecure defaults or incorrectly set up
Missing passwords, open firewall rules, default usernames still in place.
Security Policy
No policy exists, or staff are not following it
No written security rules, or people ignoring the ones that are there.

blocks.content: 4 Classes of Physical Threat

items.title: Hardware
items.description: Physical damage to servers, routers, switches, cabling, and workstations.

items.title: Environmental
items.description: Temperature extremes (too hot or cold) or humidity extremes (too wet or dry).

items.title: Electrical
items.description: Voltage spikes, brownouts (insufficient voltage), unconditioned power, or total power loss.

items.title: Maintenance
items.description: ESD damage from poor handling, lack of spare parts, poor cabling, or poor labelling.

blocks.title: üí° Physical Security Plan
blocks.content: Step 1: Lock up equipment ‚Äî prevent access via doors, ceiling, raised floor, windows, ducts, vents. Step 2: Monitor and control entry with electronic logs. Step 3: Use security cameras.

blocks.label: Malware
blocks.content: Short for malicious software. Code or software specifically designed to damage, disrupt, steal, or inflict bad action on data, hosts, or networks. Three main types: Virus, Worm, Trojan Horse.

items.title: Virus
items.description: Inserts a copy of itself into another program. Spreads when that file is transferred ‚Äî email attachments, file sharing, network. Won't activate until you open the infected file.
items.note: Host program usually keeps running after infection, but some viruses overwrite it entirely

items.title: Worm
items.description: Similar damage to a virus but completely independent ‚Äî no host program needed. Exploits system vulnerabilities to travel through the network automatically with no human help.
items.note: Key difference from virus: does not need to attach to a program to spread

items.title: Trojan Horse
items.description: Looks legitimate ‚Äî tricks you into installing it via email attachment or download. Once active: pop-ups, file deletion, data theft, spreads other malware, creates back doors.
items.note: Does NOT self-replicate by infecting other files ‚Äî must spread through user interaction

blocks.title: ‚ö° Quick Comparison
blocks.content: Virus = needs a host file to run. Worm = standalone, spreads itself. Trojan = tricks you into running it. All three are malware but they spread and operate differently ‚Äî exam will test this distinction.
Beyond malware, networks face three major categories of attack. Threat actors often run reconnaissance first to gather information before launching access or denial of service attacks.
üîç Reconnaissance Attacks ‚Äî Scouting the Target

blocks.label: Reconnaissance Attack
blocks.content: The discovery and mapping of systems, services, or vulnerabilities. The threat actor is gathering information before doing anything else ‚Äî finding out what's there and where the weak points are.

items.title: Internet Queries
items.description: Using tools like Google, whois, and nslookup to find the target's IP address space and organisational information.
items.note: The starting point ‚Äî free information gathering

items.title: Ping Sweeps
items.description: Tools like fping or gping systematically ping every address in a subnet to find which hosts are active.
items.note: Like calling every number in a phone book to see who answers

items.title: Port Scans
items.description: Probing which ports are open on target devices to identify what services are running and where.
items.note: Tells the attacker exactly what to target next

blocks.content: üîê Access Attacks ‚Äî Breaking In

blocks.label: Access Attack
blocks.content: The unauthorized manipulation of data, system access, or user privileges. Goal is to get into systems and access information you have no right to view.

items.title: Password Attacks
items.description: Three methods: brute-force (automated guessing), Trojan horse (capture passwords), packet sniffers (read credentials off the wire).

items.title: Trust Exploitation
items.description: Abusing trusted relationships between devices or user accounts to gain access that should not be possible.

items.title: Port Redirection
items.description: Redirecting traffic meant for one host through a compromised host ‚Äî the attacker intercepts it on the way.

items.title: Man-in-the-Middle
items.description: Sitting between two communicating parties and reading or modifying the traffic without either side knowing.

blocks.content: üí• Denial of Service ‚Äî Flooding

blocks.label: Denial of Service (DoS)
blocks.content: Disabling or corrupting networks, systems, or services by consuming all system resources with traffic. Prevents legitimate users from using the service. Most publicised form of attack and among the most difficult to eliminate.

left.label: DoS
left.content: Single source floods the target. Relatively simple to run ‚Äî even unskilled threat actors can do it. Interrupts communication and causes significant loss of time and money.

right.label: DDoS
right.content: Multiple coordinated sources. Uses a botnet ‚Äî a network of infected hosts called zombies. A command and control (CnC) program instructs the zombies to attack.

blocks.note: Both prevent legitimate access. DDoS is much harder to stop because the traffic comes from everywhere.

blocks.label: Defense-in-Depth
blocks.content: Also called a layered approach. A combination of networking devices and services working together to protect the network. No single point of failure ‚Äî if one layer is breached, others still protect you.
Security Devices & Services

items.title: VPN
items.description: Provides secure encrypted tunnels for remote access and connections between corporate sites.

items.title: ASA Firewall
items.description: Dedicated stateful firewall. Internal traffic can go out and come back ‚Äî external traffic cannot initiate connections to inside hosts.

items.title: IPS
items.description: Intrusion Prevention System. Monitors incoming and outgoing traffic looking for malware and attack signatures. Stops threats in real time.

items.title: ESA / WSA
items.description: Email Security Appliance filters spam and suspicious emails. Web Security Appliance filters known and suspicious malware sites.

items.title: AAA Server
items.description: Secure database of who is authorised to access and manage network devices. Devices authenticate admin users against this.

items.title: DMZ
items.description: Demilitarized Zone ‚Äî a special network for servers that need to be reachable from outside (web servers, DNS, etc).

blocks.label: AAA (Triple-A)
blocks.content: Authentication, Authorization, and Accounting. Controls: WHO is permitted to access the network (authenticate), WHAT actions they can perform (authorize), and keeps a record of WHAT was done (accounting). Think of it like a credit card ‚Äî it identifies you, sets your spending limit, and logs every transaction.
Firewalls ‚Äî How They Filter Traffic

rows: Packet Filtering
Allows or denies traffic based on IP or MAC addresses.
Application Filtering
Allows or denies access by specific application types based on port numbers.
URL Filtering
Allows or denies access to websites based on specific URLs or keywords.
Stateful Packet Inspection (SPI)
Incoming packets must be legitimate responses to requests from internal hosts. Unsolicited packets are blocked. Can also detect DoS attacks.

blocks.title: üí° DMZ in Practice
blocks.content: Servers accessible to outside users (web servers, email, DNS) sit in the DMZ. The firewall allows controlled access to the DMZ from the internet, but the internal network stays protected behind it. The firewall applies specific policies to hosts in the DMZ.
Backups ‚Äî 4 Key Considerations

rows: Frequency
Regular schedule per security policy. Full backups monthly or weekly ‚Äî frequent partial backups of changed files in between.
Storage
Always validate backups to ensure data integrity. Test the restoration procedures ‚Äî make sure you can actually restore from them.
Security
Transport backups to an approved offsite location on a daily, weekly, or monthly rotation as the security policy requires.
Validation
Protect backups with strong passwords. The password is required to restore the data ‚Äî without it the backup is useless.

blocks.content: Upgrades, Updates & Patches

items: Most effective way to stop a worm attack: download security updates from the OS vendor and patch all vulnerable systems.
Create a standard software image (approved OS + applications) deployed on new or upgraded systems.
Already-deployed systems may still need updated security patches ‚Äî don't assume they're current.
Best practice: enable automatic updates so security patches download and install without user intervention.

blocks.content: Endpoint Security

items: Endpoints (laptops, desktops, servers, phones, tablets) are one of the hardest areas to secure because of human behaviour.
Companies must have well-documented policies ‚Äî and employees must actually be aware of them.
Standard measures: antivirus software and host intrusion prevention on every endpoint.
More comprehensive solutions rely on network access control (NAC) to check devices before they join the network.

blocks.content: Default security settings on new devices are almost always inadequate. These are the steps and commands to harden Cisco routers and switches before they go into production.
First Steps ‚Äî Any Device, Any OS

items: Change default usernames and passwords immediately ‚Äî they are well known and the first thing attackers try.
Restrict access to system resources to only the people who are authorised to use them.
Turn off and uninstall any unnecessary services and applications.
Devices from the manufacturer may have been in a warehouse for months ‚Äî update software and install all security patches before connecting to the network.

blocks.content: Cisco AutoSecure

blocks.code: Router# auto secure                  ‚Üê single command, automatically hardens the router

blocks.content: Strong Passwords ‚Äî The Rules

items: Minimum 8 characters ‚Äî 10+ is better. Longer is always more secure.
Mix uppercase, lowercase, numbers, symbols, and spaces (if allowed).
Avoid dictionary words, personal info (birthdate, pet name), or repeated patterns.
Change passwords regularly to limit the window if one is compromised.
Never write passwords down and leave them somewhere obvious.

left.label: WEAK passwords
left.content: secret ‚Äî dictionary word. smith ‚Äî mother's maiden name. toyota ‚Äî make of car. bob1967 ‚Äî name + birthday. Blueleaf23 ‚Äî simple word + numbers.

right.label: STRONG passwords
right.content: b67n42d39c ‚Äî alphanumeric mix. 12^h u4@1p7 ‚Äî alphanumeric + symbols + space. Use passphrases: multiple words with spaces are long and memorable.

blocks.note: On Cisco routers, leading spaces are ignored but spaces after the first character count ‚Äî use this to build strong passphrases.

blocks.content: Password Hardening Commands

rows: service password-encryption
Encrypts all plaintext passwords in the running config so they can't be read if someone views it.
security password min-length 8
Enforces a minimum password length of 8 characters ‚Äî any shorter and it won't be accepted.
login block-for 120 attempts 3 within 60
Blocks all login attempts for 120 seconds if there are 3 failed attempts within 60 seconds. Stops brute-force attacks.
exec-timeout 5 30
Auto-logs out an inactive session after 5 minutes and 30 seconds. Default is 10 minutes ‚Äî always reduce this.

blocks.title: üí° Where exec-timeout applies
blocks.content: This is a line configuration command ‚Äî applies to console, auxiliary, and vty lines individually. Default Cisco timeout is 10 minutes of inactivity. An admin who walks away from an open privileged EXEC session is a major security risk.
SSH Setup ‚Äî 6 Steps in Order
Telnet sends everything unencrypted ‚Äî never use it on production devices. SSH encrypts all traffic. These 6 steps must be done in this order:

steps.description: Configure a unique hostname. Must not be the factory default.
Set the IP domain name. Combined with the hostname, this is used to generate the encryption key.

steps.command: crypto key generate rsa general-keys modulus 1024
steps.description: Generate the RSA encryption key. Range is 360‚Äì2048 bits. Minimum recommended is 1024. Larger = more secure but slower to encrypt/decrypt.
Create a local database user. The 'secret' keyword encrypts the password using MD5.
Tell the vty lines to authenticate against the local user database we just created.
Only allow SSH sessions in on the vty lines. This blocks Telnet. By default no input sessions are allowed ‚Äî this enables SSH.

blocks.content: Disable Unused Services
Routers and switches start with services active that you may not need. Every open service is an attack surface. Check what's open, then shut anything you don't use.

rows: show ip ports all
IOS-XE: lists all open ports on the device. IOS-XE typically only has HTTPS (443) and DHCP (67) open by default.
show control-plane host open-ports
Older IOS versions: same job as above. You may see this on older gear ‚Äî older IOS often leaves HTTP (80) and Telnet (23) open.
no ip http server
Disables the insecure HTTP server (port 80). Use HTTPS only.
transport input ssh
On the vty lines ‚Äî disables Telnet (port 23), allows SSH only.

blocks.title: üí° Key Takeaways
blocks.content: Telnet = unencrypted = never use on production. SSH = encrypted = always use. service password-encryption on every device. Default timeout is 10 minutes ‚Äî reduce it. IOS-XE defaults are safer than older IOS ‚Äî but always verify with show ip ports all. AutoSecure does most of this in one command if you need a quick start.
